title: Jacob Rees-Mogg sparks outrage by walking out of Commons during Brexit confusion
text:

Jacob Rees-Mogg was branded a disgrace for walking out of the Commons while MPs were trying to work out the Government's rapidly unravelling plan.

MPs were heard shouting "outrageous, absolutely outrageous" and "disgrace" as the Leader of the Commons ambled out of the chamber without waiting for MPs to finish their points of order.

Members, who had been sitting for the first time on a Saturday in 37 years, were trying to clear up confusion sparked by Mr Rees-Mogg's announcement of the Government's plans after being dealt a humiliating defeat on Brexit .

Mr Rees-Mogg had just made a statement suggesting the Government planned to bring a Meaningful Vote on Brexit on Monday.

But there was a great deal of confusion, due to a a convention in parliament that the same question cannot be put twice during the same session.

The government had tried to get lawmakers to approve the deal on Saturday but lawmakers instead backed a proposal to withhold support for the deal until formal ratification legislation has passed.

There was also confusion because Mr Rees-Mogg had made the announcement in a "point of order", rather than an emergency business statement, which would have allowed MPs to ask him questions.

Speaker John Bercow had already told Mr Rees-Mogg: "I will reflect on it and give what I hope is a fully considered ruling on this matter on Monday. I will do so of course having taken advice in appropriate quarters,"

"The government is not the arbiter of what is orderly."

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

Mr Bercow invited Leader of the House of Commons Jacob Rees-Mogg to come to the despatch box saying at the moment there "is extreme ambiguity about intention" adding that "cannot be right".

Mr Rees-Mogg said: "I think you worry unduly, that there will be a full emergency business statement on Monday, which is part of what I was saying so that people will have a full appreciation of what business there will be."

He added: "The Queen's Speech debate will continue but Monday will be as I set out on the point of order I raised a few moments ago."

Labour's Hilary Benn (Leeds Central) asked if Mr Bercow would be willing to accept a manuscript amendment to any motion tabled by the Government "once we know what your ruling is on Monday".

Mr Bercow replied: "I do not want the House to be disadvantaged."

He added: "It must be right that there should be an opportunity for manuscript amendments to be tabled so that alternative propositions can be put before the House."

In the absence of being allowed to ask questions on the Government's plans, MPs raised a number of 'points of order' asking for an explanation.

But before they had completed their points of order, Mr Rees-Mogg stood up and walked out of the Chamber.

The SNP's Patrick Grady, who was asking a question of the chair at the time, sighed, gestured towards the departing Leader, and said: "Mr Speaker, I'm not sure I have a point of order any more."
description: The leader of the house didn't bother waiting for points of order on the Government's rapidly unravelling plan to be asked
